title: 112_hr3012
content: The Act titled "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" imposes a numerical limitation on visas from any single foreign state. The "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act by making changes to visa allocation and numerical limitations. The "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act by making changes to visa allocation and numerical limitations. It includes amendments to sections 202 and 203, such as changing subsection numbers and special rules for countries at the visa ceiling. The "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act by making changes to visa allocation and numerical limitations. It includes amendments to sections 202 and 203, such as adjusting subsection numbers and implementing special rules for countries reaching the visa ceiling. The "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" adjusts visa allocation and numerical limitations under sections 202 and 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. It ensures that immigrant visas for natives of a single foreign state do not exceed specified limits, allocating visa numbers proportionally among different categories. The "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" adjusts visa allocation under sections 202 and 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to ensure proportional allocation of visa numbers among different categories. The Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992 is amended to reflect these changes. The "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" adjusts visa allocation under sections 202 and 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to ensure proportional allocation of visa numbers among different categories. The Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992 is amended to reflect these changes, including a country-specific offset and transition rules for employment-based immigrants. The amendments made by this section will be effective as if enacted on September 30, 2011, and will apply to fiscal years starting from fiscal year 2012. The amendments made by the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" will be effective as of September 30, 2011, and will apply to fiscal years starting from 2012. Transition rules for employment-based immigrants will also be implemented. Transition rules for employment-based immigrants under the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" allocate 15 percent of immigrant visas for fiscal year 2012 to natives of certain foreign states or dependent areas. For fiscal year 2013, a portion of immigrant visas under certain paragraphs will be allocated to natives of foreign states with lower visa numbers in fiscal year 2010. For fiscal year 2013, 10 percent of immigrant visas under certain paragraphs will be allotted to immigrants from foreign states with lower visa numbers in fiscal year 2011. For fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under certain paragraphs will be allotted to immigrants from foreign states with lower visa numbers in fiscal year 2012. For fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas will be allotted to immigrants from foreign states with lower visa numbers in fiscal year 2012. Additionally, the number of reserved visas for natives of any single foreign state or dependent area may not exceed 25. In fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas will be allocated to immigrants from foreign states with lower visa numbers in fiscal year 2012. The number of reserved visas for natives of any single foreign state or dependent area may not exceed 25 percent. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, immigrant visas under section 203(b) of the Act will be allotted with restrictions on the percentage allocated to natives of any single foreign state. The maximum allocation for a single foreign state is 25 percent, while for a dependent area, it is 2 percent. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, immigrant visas under section 203(b) of the Act will be allotted with restrictions on the percentage allocated to natives of any single foreign state, not exceeding 85 percent. If the operation of certain subsections prevents the total number of immigrant visas from being issued, a special rule will apply. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, immigrant visas under section 203(b) of the Act will be allotted with restrictions on the percentage allocated to natives of any single foreign state, not exceeding 85 percent. A special rule allows for the issuance of visas if the total number available would not be issued otherwise. Section 202(b) of the Act applies to determine the foreign state to which an alien is chargeable. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on November 29, 2011, as attested by Karen L. Haas, the Clerk.
